summary.p: An incomplete copy of the play entitled Cāraṅkataraṉ Vācakappā. It contains the complete Act II and a part of Act III.

The author is not mentioned, to our knowledge, in the manuscript. There are several known Tamil versions of the play, such as a three-Act Tamil version attributed to Maṇikkappiḷḷai by Lamairesse (1867: 212), a manuscript drama composed by Ciṅkāravēlu Mutaliyār and a Cāraṅkataraṉ composed in 1912 by Pammal Campanta Mutaliyār (Cāraṅkataraṉ Yaṭcakkāṉam 1996: 26). Given the contents of the text, characters’ names and stage directions, the present manuscript seems to match Maṇikkappiḷḷai’s play, for which Lamairesse gives a full synopsis (1867: 217-227) and translated excerpts (1867: 233-291).
Versified text of characters’ speeches interspersed with some narrative passages in prose; stage directions giving characters’ names and sometimes raga or verse indications.
King Rācēntiraṉ consults his ministers and generals on whether he should punish his son Cāraṅkataraṉ, falsely accused of rape by his stepmother Cittiraṅki and her maid.

Despite being warned by his ministers who tell him he should never trust a woman, the king, manipulated by Cittiraṅki, sentences Cāraṅkataraṉ to have his left leg and right wrist amputated, in accordance with the rule laid down by the Brahmins. Cāraṅkataraṉ’s mother Rattiṉaṅki tries to persuade the king to spare their son, all to no avail.
The executioners Ciṅkappallaṉ, Kokkumūkkaṉ and Kuraṅkaṉ take the prince to the forest to carry out the sentence with the convict’s full consent.

As a mutilated Cāraṅkataraṉ laments on his fate, a celestial oracle comes to explain his misfortunes by a treachery he had committed in a previous life. After the oracle is gone, cittars arrive to heal his wound and make his limbs grow back.
The executioners, who have witnessed the scene, go back and report it to the king.
New consultation of King Rācēntiraṉ with his ministers and generals. The king confronts Cittiraṅki, who discards the oracle's intervention and demands that the executioners be executed for perjury.
The oracle speaks out; Cittiraṅki is confounded. The executioners throw her into a lime kiln and then gouge out the eyes of her servant before giving her to wild beasts.

The king and Rattiṉaṅki, accompanied by Cāraṅkataraṉ's best friend Cumantaṉ, set out into the forest in search of the prince. The latter, who has become a cittar, renounces the throne in favour of Cumantan.
The king returns to the palace.
Dimensions assessed at the time of examination.

extent.note: The leaves are broader in their middle than at their edges.

collation.desc: 1 bifolio = Cāraṅkataraṉ Vācakappā: Title Page of Act II. Tamil foliation {1}. Verso blank. 540 x 35 mm (truncated).
55 folios = Cāraṅkataraṉ Vācakappā: Act II. Tamil foliation {2}, 3-56.
1 folio = Cāraṅkataraṉ Vācakappā: Title Page of Act III. No foliation. Verso blank. 460 x 30 mm (truncated).
65 folios = Cāraṅkataraṉ Vācakappā: Act III. Tamil foliation {1}, 2-62, [6]3, [6]4, [65]. Folio 65 incomplete in 3 fragments.

supportDesc.condition: Average state of preservation, some leaves are broken, truncated, damaged by wormholes, stained, stuck together.

layoutDesc.layout: Layout in columns (various numbers of columns), with some exceptions (e.g. U2, f41r). Stanzas regularly distributed aṭi-wise per line and final letter(s) indented to the right at the end of lines.

origin.origDate: Internally dated to the year kīlaka of the Jovian cycle and to CE 1848. See colophon (U2, f56v, column 5, lines 2-3).

provenance.p: Owned by René Vigier. The BnF register notes: Manuscrit tamoul gravé sur feuilles de palmier (drame tiré de l'histoire du roi Sharangadara). Rapporté de Vientiane (Ht Laos) par René Vigier, oncle du Commt Vigier, avant 1910.

acquisition.p: Bequest no. 9186 according to Cabaton (1912, handwritten addition, f8v, no. 1038). Received in 1951 from Commt Vigier. See BnF, département des Manuscrits, inventaire 11 = Dons : manuscrits et imprimés documentaires, 1948-1965, no. 9186.

encodingDesc.p: General ― Unmarked length of ō and ē supplied. Unmarked puḷḷi supplied. Conjectural reading (text unclear) between parentheses. Supplied reading (text lost) between square brackets. Alternative readings separated by slash. In transliteration ― Unmarked elided overshort u supplied as an apostrophe. Uppercase for initial vowels. Symbols between curly brackets. Abbreviations ― c = column; f = folio; lf = library foliation; lm = left margin; r = recto; rm = right margin; u / U followed by a number = unit (codicological and/or textual); v = verso.
